questions.text:
Match the following MRI images with their respective imaging sequence.
  1. T1-weighted MRI
  2. T2-weighted MRI
  3. Susceptibility weighted MRI
  4. FLAIR
questions.solution:
The correct match is 1-C, 2-D, 3-A, 4-B.

The simple way to classify the image would be using the following rule of thumb:

Sequence White Matter Grey Matter CSF
T1 Brighter Darker Dark
T2 Darker Brighter Bright
FLAIR Darker Brighter Dark

 

T1 weighting is one of the basic MRI pulse sequences. The difference in the appearance of various tissues is due to their different T1 relaxation times. CSF has a long T1 time and appears dark. T2 weighting is also a basic MRI pulse sequence. It is based on the T2 relaxation time of the tissues. CSF appears bright in these images.

The MRI image below is a susceptibility-weighted image(SWI) as it clearly demonstrates microhemorrhages as hypointense foci.

SWI is a form of MRI sequence that is especially sensitive to substances that distort the local magnetic field. Compounds with diamagnetic, paramagnetic, and ferromagnetic properties will interact with the local magnetic field and produce distraction. This would lead to a loss of signal in these areas.

Deoxyhemoglobin, hemosiderin, and ferritin are paramagnetic. Bone minerals and dystrophic calcifications are diamagnetic in nature. The main clinical use is the identification of microhemorrhages/blood products or calcium that are not detected in other MRI sequences.

Inversion recovery sequences:

This MRI sequence is used to selectively null certain tissues. It can be:

  • Short tau inversion recovery (STIR), where fat is nulled. Fluids appear bright and fat appears dark in these images.
  • Fluid attenuated inversion recovery (FLAIR) or double inversion recovery (DIR), where fluid is nulled. The fluid (CSF) normally appears dark and lesions appear to be brighter in these images.

FLAIR image-

Other imaging sequences:

Proton density image:

It is based on the number of nuclei in the area that is imaged. In a PD-weighted image, tissues with a higher density of protons produce stronger signals and appear brighter. PD weighted image can be identified by comparing fluid with the fat signal. Fluids in these images appear greyish white similar or the appearance of fat in the body.

 

Gradient echo sequences(GRE): 

It uses gradient fields to generate transverse magnetization. In areas of hemorrhage, the iron that is present in the hemoglobin, produces its own local magnetic field and dephases the spinning nuclei. This is useful to identify hemorrhagic contusions in the brain and pigmented villonodular synovitis.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman who was operated for a femur fracture complains of shortness of breath on the fourth postoperative day. She has chest pain and tachycardia as well. Her chest X-ray is shown below. This finding is most probably suggestive of ________.
questions.solution:
The given clinical features and the X-ray showing Hampton's hump is suggestive of pulmonary embolism.

Pulmonary embolism:

Pulmonary embolism refers to embolic occlusion of the pulmonary arterial system.

Most patients present with pleuritic chest pain, dyspnoea, and tachypnoea. The classical clinical triad of sudden onset of chest pain, dyspnoea, and hemoptysis is present in only a few cases.

Chest x-ray signs related to pulmonary embolism include:

  • Hampton's hump is a pleural-based, wedge-shaped opacity with the apex of the triangle pointed towards the occluding vessel or hilum and implies lung infarction. 
  • Westermark sign is a chest X-ray finding in pulmonary embolism. It is defined by a hyperlucent area with decreased vascularity due to oligemia of the involved part of the lung.
  • Chest x-ray: A large part of the right hemithorax is hypodense due to oligaemia, secondary to vasoconstriction distal to an embolus.
  • Fleishner sign: Enlarged pulmonary artery.
  • Knuckle or sausage sign, describing a dilatation of a central pulmonary artery due to occlusion by the embolus with collapse or constriction of the distal arteries resulting in an abrupt tapering of these arteries.
  • Palla’s sign: Dilated right descending pulmonary artery (Image below):
  • Melting sign: infarct shows rapid clearing in contrast to pneumonic consolidation.
  • Elevated hemidiaphragm.
  • The best known indirect sign of PE on transthoracic echo is McConnell's sign. That is hypokinesis of the right ventricular free wall with the normal motion of the right ventricle apex.

Related Pearl: Chest X Ray signs in pulmonary embolism

Westermark's sign: Focal area of oligemia (decreased vascular markings) distal to the embolism.

Hampton's hump: Peripherally placed wedge-shaped or dome-shaped opacity due to infarction of lung tissue.

Palla's sign: Increased size of the right descending pulmonary artery with a sausage-like appearance.

Fleishner sign: enlarged pulmonary artery.

Melting sign: an infarct shows rapid clearing in contrast to pneumonic consolidation.

McConnell's sign (indirect sign of PE seen in transthoracic echo): hypokinesis of the right ventricular free wall with normal motion of the right ventricle apex.

Knuckle or sausage’ sign: dilatation of the pulmonary artery, proximal to the embolus with collapse or constriction of the distal arteries resulting in an abrupt tapering of these arteries.  

Note - A normal chest X-ray does not rule out pulmonary embolism in a patient with unexplained acute tachypnea or hypoxemia.

questions.text:
Match the following X-rays and their diagnoses.

A. Monteggia fracture
B. Torus fracture
C. Greenstick fracture
D. Galeazzi fracture
questions.solution:
The correct option is 1 - B, 2 - D, 3 - A, 4 - C. 

Torus fractures occur due to 'buckling' of the metaphyseal cortex as a result of compression. Due to the presence of malleable bone and a thick protective periosteum, long bone injuries result in deformation without a break in the cortex. 

The X-ray will appear as bulging of the cortex. 

The following image shows a torus fracture. 

 

Galeazzi fracture-dislocation involves a fracture of the lower third of the radius with dislocation or subluxation of the distal radioulnar joint. 

The following image shows a Galeazzi fracture-dislocation.

 

Monteggia fracture-dislocation involves a fracture of the upper third of the ulna with dislocation of the head of the radius. 

The following image shows a Monteggia fracture-dislocation

 

Greenstick fractures are partial-thickness fractures. They mostly occur in the pediatric population. Here, the cortex and periosteum are interrupted only on one side, but are intact on the other side. This is because children's bones are not yet ossified and mostly consist of pliable cartilage that is able to bow and bend under stress that would normally cause fractures in adult bones. In addition, the periosteum is thicker and more active which reduces the chances of open fractures. 

They usually occur in long bones, particularly the upper limb due to falling on an outstretched hand.

The below image depicts both forearm bone (radius and ulna) fractures. The cortex and periosteum are interrupted on one side but are uninterrupted on the other side.  

Related Pearl: Named fractures of the upper limb

Colle's fracture: Extra-articular fracture of the distal radius with dorsal angulation of the distal bone fragment.

 

Galeazzi fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the lower third of the radius and subluxation of the distal radio-ulnar joint.

 

Monteggia fracture-dislocation: Fracture of the shaft of the ulna with dislocation of a proximal radio-ulnar joint.

 

Barton’s fracture: Intra-articular fracture of the distal radius. Barton's fracture can be dorsal or volar (reverse Barton's).

 

Rolando's fracture: Intra-articular comminuted fracture of the base of the first metacarpal with a T or Y configuration.

 

Smith's fracture: Reverse Colles' fracture. Extra-articular fracture of the distal one-third of the radius with palmar or ventral displacement (Image below).

 

Chauffeur's fracture or the Hutchinson fracture: Fracture of the radial styloid.

Essex–Lopresti lesion: Fracture of the radial head with disruption of the interosseous membrane and distal radial ulnar joint ligaments.

Nightstick fracture: Isolated fracture of radial or ulnar bone.

questions.text: A 70-year-old man presented with chronic cough, loss of weight, lower abdominal pain, and diarrhea for the past 6 months. Barium studies show the following finding. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the barium study showing the 'string' sign are suggestive of ileocaecal tuberculosis. 

Intestinal tuberculosis is caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis either secondary to pulmonary tuberculosis or by M.bovine as a primary GI infection.

The ileocaecal junction is the most common site of tuberculosis in the gastrointestinal tract. The liver, spleen, and peritoneum may also be involved in the abdomen.

Ieocaecal tuberculosis can be ulcerative or hyperplastic.

Differences between ulcerative and hyperplastic types of ileocaecal tuberculosis

Patients typically present with cough, evening rise in temperature, weight loss, malaise, abdominal pain with distension, and alternating diarrhea and constipation. On palpation, the abdomen feels doughy and a mass may be palpated in the right iliac fossa.

Barium meal follow-through study findings in ileocaecal tuberculosis include:

  • Narrowing of the terminal ileum, known as string sign, and ileocaecal junction
  • Gooseneck ileum 
  • The ileocaecal angle becomes obtuse
  • Caecum appears pulled up and hepatic flexure is pulled down
  • Conical caecum
  • Fleischner sign- refers to a widely gaping, thickened, patulous ileocaecal valve and a narrowed, ulcerated terminal ileum

Treatment includes anti-tubercular therapy and nutritional support. Surgery may be indicated in complications like intestinal obstruction, perforation, hemorrhage, intra-abdominal abscess formation, or fistula formation.

Option B: Apple core sign is characteristically seen in the barium enema of carcinoma colon as shown below.

Option C: Crohn's disease is an inflammatory bowel disease that shows the string sign of Kantor on barium enema as shown below.

Option D: The image below shows the lead-pipe appearance of the colon on the barium enema. This finding is seen in ulcerative colitis due to the loss of haustra in the diseased colonic segment.

Related Pearl: Barium studies in GI tuberculosis

  • Earliest feature is spasm and hypermotility, with edema of the valve.
  • Thickening of the valve lips, with narrowing of the terminal ileum: Fleischner or inverted umbrella sign is characteristic of TB.
  • In advance disease, the characteristic deformity includes symmetric, annular, napkin-ring stenosis and obstruction or shortening and pouch formation.
  • The cecum is shrunken and retracts out of the iliac fossa due to contraction of the mesocolon: Pulled-up cecum
  • Loss of ileocecal angle with dilated terminal ileum: Gooseneck deformity
  • Narrowing of the terminal ileum due to irritability, along with shortened rigid cecum: Sterlein sign
  • Persistent narrow stream of barium in the bowel indicates stenosis: String sign

questions.text: Match the following mammogram images with their diagnoses.

choices.text: 1- Duct ectasia  2- Malignancy  3- Traumatic fat necrosis   4- Fibroadenoma
1- Traumatic fat necrosis   2- Fibroadenoma  3- Malignancy  4-Duct ectasia
1- Fibroadenoma   2- Traumatic fat necrosis   3- Duct ectasia   4- Malignancy
1- Malignancy  2- Duct ectasia  3- Fibroadenoma   4-Traumatic fat necrosis

questions.solution:
The correct match is:

1- Traumatic fat necrosis 
2- Fibroadenoma 
3- Malignancy
4- Duct ectasia

Egg-shell calcification or lead pipe calcification is seen in traumatic fat necrosis. Usually seen with a  previous history of surgery or trauma. There are egg-shell calcifications in the wall of an oil cyst or as coarse dystrophic calcifications with scarring. 


Popcorn calcification is seen in fibroadenoma. These are the most common benign masses of the breast. On mammograms, they present as rounded or oval masses with coarse calcifications (popcorn calcifications) as shown in the image below.


Breast malignancies appear as ill-defined spiculated masses with microcalcifications as shown in the image below.


Duct ectasias present with broken needle calcifications. This occurs due to the calcification of debris within dilated ducts. Most of the time, these are bilateral.

questions.text: A mother with polyhydramnios delivered a baby at term gestation. She was unable to feed the baby as it choked on the milk. She also noticed the baby's abdomen appeared distended. Vesicular breath sounds in bilateral lung fields and abdominal distension were noted on examination. An attempt to pass a nasogastric tube fails. An X-ray is ordered and appears as shown. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given symptoms of choking and abdominal distention with a failure to pass a nasogastric tube and an X-ray showing NG tube in proximal esophagus and stomach distended with gas suggests the presence of a tracheoesophageal fistula (TEF).

A tracheoesophageal fistula is an abnormal fistula communication between the esophagus and trachea. Among the different types, Type C is the most common type. It consists of proximal esophageal atresia and distal TEF. With each breath, the air enters the distal esophagus and the stomach causing gastric distention which presents as abdominal distention. 

Inability to pass a nasogastric (NG) tube is a crucial pointer in the diagnosis of esophageal atresia. 

Tracheoesophageal fistula is associated with VACTERL (vertebral, anorectal, cardiac, tracheal, esophageal, renal, and limb) anomalies.


Other options:

Option A - Foreign body in the trachea will present with decreased air entry bilaterally in the lungs and stridor.

Option B - Gastric volvulus may also be associated with abdominal distension and difficulty in passing the NG tube into the stomach. However, in this case, the tube is seen stuck in the proximal esophagus itself making the diagnosis of TEF more likely.

Option D - Congenital diaphragmatic hernia is usually left-sided and presents with respiratory distress. On examination, bowel sounds are heard in the chest field as abdominal contents herniate into the chest. There is a scaphoid abdomen rather than a distended abdomen as in this case.

Related Pearl: Types of Tracheo-esophageal Fistula/Esophageal Atresia

Abbreviations:

  • EA: Esophageal atresia
  • TEF: Tracheo-esophageal Fistula

questions.text: The sign shown in the given ultrasound image of the lung is seen in:
questions.solution:
The given ultrasound image of the lung shows the barcode sign or stratosphere sign which is seen in pneumothorax.

On M mode, classical signs for the grayscale imaging are seen:
• Seashore sign: normal lung
• Barcode/stratosphere sign: pneumothorax


The given M-mode image in the question demonstrates a linear, laminar pattern in the tissue superficial to the pleural line and a similar linear pattern deep to the pleural line. This phenomenon, known as the stratosphere sign or barcode sign indicates absent lung sliding and suggests the presence of pneumothorax at this.

The M-mode image of a normal lung demonstrates a linear, laminar pattern in the tissue superficial to the pleural line and a granular or sandy appearance deep to the pleural line. This phenomenon is known as the seashore sign and it indicates normal lung sliding and excludes pneumothorax at this interspace.

Other options:

Option B: Pleural effusion on ultrasound appears anechoic with an echogenic line at the fluid-lung interface if it is transudate. Exudative and hemorrhagic effusions may appear echogenic with pleural thickening. The fluid shows movement and changes in shape with breathing, along with the presence of septa and fibrous strands.

Option C: Consolidation on ultrasound appears hypoechoic with heterogeneous echotexture. It is isoechoic with the liver and is referred to as lung hepatization. 

Option D: A collapsed lung under a large effusion will be seen as a hyperechoic wedge-shaped area.

questions.text: A patient presented with a 3-week history of dry cough and dyspnea on exertion. Gallium-67 nuclear scan of this patient showed the lambda sign. This sign involves all the following structures except:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the lambda sign on the gallium-67 scan suggest that the patient has sarcoidosis. Gallium-67 scan does not involve the left paratracheal nodes.

The image given below shows the panda sign (A) and the lambda sign (B) on the gallium-67 scan seen in sarcoidosis.

The lambda sign seen on gallium-67 scans is the gallium equivalent of the 1-2-3 sign or Pawnbrokers sign seen in the setting of thoracic sarcoidosis. It involves:

  • Right paratracheal nodes
  • Right hilar nodes
  • Left hilar nodes

1-2-3 sign or Pawnbrokers sign is a lymph node enlargement pattern on chest X-rays. It is also known as the Garland triad and involves the same three groups of lymph nodes. It is shown below.

The chest radiograph is the preferred tool used to stage sarcoidosis.

Stage 1 Bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy (usually symmetrical); right paratracheal nodes often enlarged
Stage 2  Bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy and parenchymal infiltrates
Stage 3 Parenchymal infiltrates without bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy
Stage 4  Pulmonary fibrosis

questions.text: A young farmer on a hike developed sudden shortness of breath, chest pain, and cough with salty phlegm. He was rushed to the emergency and stabilized. A CT scan showed the following. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the CT image showing the 'water lily sign' is suggestive of a ruptured pulmonary hydatid cyst.

Hydatid disease or echinococcosis is a zoonotic infection caused by the Echinococcus species of flatworms. Its life cycle consists of dogs as definitive hosts and humans as intermediate hosts.

Primary hydatid cysts most commonly occur in the liver. Most patients are asymptomatic but when symptomatic, the patient presents with hepatomegaly, pain, and obstructive jaundice.

The 2nd most common site is the lung, specifically the lower lobe of the right lung. Symptomatic patients present with cough with salty phlegm, fever, chest pain, and, hemoptysis. Silent cysts may present as an emergency due to rupture.

Computed tomography (CT) scan is accurate for detecting hydatid cysts. If there is disruption of the inner layers of the cyst, the following signs may be noted:

  • Water lily sign/ camalote sign - air-fluid level with a floating membrane (as shown below)
  • Rising sun sign/ serpent sign - a double-wall, dry cyst with crumpled membranes lying at its bottom 
  • Empty cyst sign - when all the contents are removed 

Ultrasound is the most commonly used modality to diagnose echinococcus. The ultrasound of an active hydatid cyst shows multiple septations and a rosette or honeycomb appearance (as shown below)

Serology: Detection of serum anti-echinococcal antibodies using indirect hemagglutination (IHA), indirect immunofluorescence, ELISA, and slide latex agglutination test can be used to support the clinical diagnosis.

Treatment :

Pulmonary hydatid disease the mainstay of treatment is surgery. Various surgeries that may be performed are cystotomy, segmentectomy, pneumonectomy, etc. 

Hepatic hydatid disease in the early stages can be treated with puncture, aspiration, injection, and re-aspiration (PAIR). Albendazole 4 days before the procedure, continued till 4 weeks afterward. Surgery is the treatment of choice when PAIR is not possible. The preferred surgical approach is pericystectomy. Since recurrence is common, pre and postoperative albendazole for 2 years is recommended.

Other options: 

Option B: A CT scan in acute pulmonary edema would show peribronchial opacities (batwing distribution) and thickening of interlobular septae in the lung base and apex (corresponds to Kerley lines on X-ray).

Option C: A CT scan in acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) is likely to show bilateral pulmonary infiltrates. 

Option D: A CT scan in acute mountain sickness (AMS) is likely to reveal patchy opacities, most often in the right middle lobe. The common presenting features are cyanosis, tachypnoea, tachycardia, and elevated body temperature. AMS may also lead to the development of non-cardiogenic high-altitude pulmonary edema.

Related Pearl: Indications and contraindications of puncture, aspiration, injection, and re-aspiration (PAIR) in hydatid cyst

Indications:

  • Relapse cyst, infected cyst, cyst >5 cm in different liver segments
  • Patients who refuse surgery or where surgery is contraindicated
  • Pregnant women, children < 3 years of age
  • WHO - type CE1 and type CE3a (transitional cyst)

Contraindications:

  • Cysts in lung
  • Cysts communicating with bile duct
  • Cysts with multiple septae—honeycomb cysts
  • Inaccessible cysts
  • Hyperechogenic cysts
  • Calcified cysts

questions.text: A 3-day old neonate of a diabetic mother presents with progressively deepening cyanosis and tachypnea since birth. The chest X-ray of the neonate is shown below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A clinical scenario of an infant born to a diabetic mother, presenting with progressive cyanosis and tachypnea with an X-ray showing the egg-on-side appearance is suggestive of transposition of great arteries. 

TGA is the most specific heart disease in infants of diabetic mothers and is more common in males. The deoxygenated blood returning from the body goes inappropriately out the aorta and back to the body again, while oxygenated pulmonary venous blood is returned directly to the lungs. Survival in the immediate neonatal period is due to the mixture of oxygenated and deoxygenated blood provided by the foramen ovale and the ductus arteriosus. 50% of patients also have a ventricular septal defect (VSD).

Chest X-rays show mild cardiomegaly, a narrow mediastinum (the classic egg-shaped heart or egg-on-string appearance) shown in the image below with normal to increased pulmonary blood flow. Egg-on-string or globular-shaped heart is due to an abnormal convexity of the right atrial border and left atrial enlargement, and therefore appears like an egg.

An ECHO confirms the transposed ventricular-arterial connection and is diagnostic. A color doppler examination is used to visualize the size of the interatrial communication and the ductus arteriosus. It also assesses the degree of mixing, and presence of any associated ventricular outflow tract obstruction, or a septal defect. 

Other options:

Option A: Total anomalous pulmonary venous return (TAPVC) occurs due to the anomalous connection of pulmonary veins instead of joining to the left atrium resulting in pulmonary venous blood reaching the right atrium. 

In supracardiac (TAPVC)  the configuration of the heart and the superior mediastinal borders resemble a snowman. It is also referred to as the figure of 8 sign as shown below.

Option B: Ebstein anomaly is a rare cyanotic congenital heart disease with diminished pulmonary blood flow due to abnormality of the tricuspid valve. 

In the Ebstein anomaly, there is severe right-sided cardiomegaly due to an elongated and enlarged right atrium which leads to an elevated apex giving a box-shaped heart as shown below.

Option C: Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF)  is the most common cyanotic heart disease encountered beyond the age of 1 year. It is characterized by tetrad of:

  • Severe right ventricle outflow obstruction
  • Large ventricular septal defect (VSD)
  • Aorta overriding VSD
  • Right ventricular hypertrophy

In the TOF, the hypertrophied right ventricle causes the rounded apical shadow to be uptilted so that it is situated higher above the diaphragm than normal. This on X-rays appears as a boot-shaped heart or Coeur en sabot as shown below.

Related Pearl: Radiological Signs in Congenital Heart Diseases

Anomaly Sign
Tetralogy of Fallot Coeur en sabot
Transposition of great vessels (TGV) Egg on string
Partial anomalous pulmonary venous return Scimitar sign
Total anomalous pulmonary venous return Snowman sign
Endocardial cushion defects Gooseneck sign
Ebstein anomaly Box-shaped heart

Related Pearl: Radiological findings in some congenital heart defects

Boot shaped heart - Tetralogy of Fallot (TOF)

 

Egg on string appearance - Transposition of Great Arteries (TGA)

 

Snowman's heart appearance or figure of 8 appearance - Supracardiac TAPVC

 

Box Shaped Heart - Ebstein's Anomaly

questions.text:
Match the following characteristic X-Ray appearances with their corresponding conditions.
  1. Large Bowel Obstruction
  2. Jejunal Obstruction
  3. Sigmoid Volvulus
  4. Caecal Volvulus
questions.solution:
The correct match is 1-D, 2-C, 3-B, 4-A.

 In small bowel obstructions like jejunal obstruction, the obstructed bowel loops are central in location and lie transversely. The jejunal obstruction shows valvulae conniventes (mucosal folds that cross the entire diameter of the bowel). It gives it a ladder effect. The distended cecum may show the presence of gas shadow in the right iliac fossa.

In large bowel obstruction, the presence of haustrations is a feature. Haustral folds are irregular and do not cross the entire diameter of the bowel. These are absent in the caecum. The given image shows haustrations in large bowel obstruction

On X-ray abdomen, the apex of the cecal volvulus points towards the left upper quadrant vs the apex pointing towards the right upper quadrant in sigmoid volvulus.

Other radiological findings in caecal volvulus include caecal dilatation, single air-fluid level, and absence of gas in the distal colon. CECT abdomen is the investigation of choice that shows a whirl sign (also seen in the midgut volvulus).

Sigmoid volvulus occurs when the sigmoid colon twists on the sigmoid mesocolon. X-ray abdomen shows a large, dilated loop of the colon, often with a few air-fluid levels. Specific signs include the coffee bean sign (seen below) and the absence of rectal gas. On X-ray abdomen, the apex of the sigmoid volvulus points towards the right upper quadrant.

questions.text: A 16-year-old patient visits the OPD with progressive deformity in the left lower limb. The x-ray of the patient is given below. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation and the x-ray showing Shepherd's crook deformity are both suggestive of fibrous dysplasia of the proximal femur. 

Fibrous dysplasia is a condition that affects bone development and is characterized by the replacement of the bone with fibrous tissue. It is commonly monostotic (involves a single bone), but in 20% of cases, it can be polyostotic.

Clinical features:

The patient presents with a progressive limb deformity or a fracture through a previously asymptomatic lesion. Presentation is often in the second decade. Other symptoms include nonspecific bone pain, tenderness, and swelling in the affected area. The commonly involved sites are the proximal femur, tibia, pelvis, and foot.

McCune-Albright syndrome: It is characterized by polyostotic fibrous dysplasia, precocious puberty, and cafe-au-lait spots with irregular borders.

Radiological findings:

  • Well-defined, expansile intramedullary lesions
  • Hazy, ground-glass appearance is seen in the majority of cases
  • Shepherd's crook deformity - Expansion with marked varus in the proximal femur

Treatment:

Bisphosphonates are used to manage bone pain. Surgical stabilization and realignment are done when there is a progressive deformity or pathological fracture. 

Other options: 

Option A: Osteoid osteoma is a benign tumor formed of osteoid and woven bone surrounded by a halo of reactive bone. It is most commonly seen in the diaphysis of the proximal femur. They most often present with pain that is classically worse at night and relieved by non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs). Plain X-ray demonstrates an area of dense sclerosis with a small rounded area of osteolysis. The preferred treatment is CT-guided radiofrequency ablation.

Option C: Chondrosarcoma is the second most common primary malignant bone tumor after osteosarcoma. It can present between the 3rd and 8th decades of life. They are slow-growing tumors that produce deep pain with an enlarging mass and arise in any bone derived from enchondral ossification. Radiographically, they appear as large, intraosseous, osteolytic tumors with irregular, granular calcifications, giving a honeycomb or popcorn appearance. CT and MRI are useful in the diagnosis. Chondrosarcoma is resistant to both chemotherapy and radiation. Surgical excision is the only treatment.

Option D: Ewing sarcoma is related to neuroectodermal tumors and arises from the mesenchymal stem cells from the bone marrow. The characteristic translocation involved is t(11:22). The tumor usually develops between 10 and 20 years of age and is usually located in the diaphysis of the long bones (femur-most common). Pain is followed by swelling and a low-grade fever. On radiography, a periosteal reaction with an 'onion peel' appearance is seen. Treatment includes preoperative chemotherapy, wide excision, and radiotherapy, if required.

questions.text:
A neonate is brought to the hospital with complaints of projectile non-bilious vomiting after feeding. An ultrasound study was done and the image is given below. Which of the following barium study signs can be seen in this condition?
  1. Shoulder sign
  2. Coffee bean sign 
  3. String sign
  4. Double-track sign
questions.solution:
The clinical features and the USG findings are suggestive of congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (CHPS). The coffee bean sign is not seen in CHPS. It is seen in sigmoid volvulus. The USG image in the question shows the cervix sign and the antral nipple sign.

Contrast studies :

  • String sign - It refers to the string-like appearance produced by the elongated pylorus with a narrow lumen as shown in the image.
  • Double-track sign - The puckering of the mucosa produces a duplicated appearance of the pylorus.
  • Caterpillar sign - Gastric hyperperistaltic waves.
  • Shoulder sign - It is produced due to the indentation of pylorus into the fluid-filled antrum.
  • Mushroom sign - It is produced due to the indentation of pylorus into the base of the duodenal bulb.

Congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis (CHPS) refers to the idiopathic thickening of gastric py­loric musculature which then results in progressive gastric outlet obstruction. It is more common in first-born male babies. The common age of presentation is 2-8 weeks.

The infants present with progressively worsening non-bilious projectile vomiting. The presence of an olive-shaped mass in the upper abdomen is pathognomonic. Characteristic metabolic abnormality includes hypokalemic hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis due to recurrent vomiting. 

Ultrasound is the first investigation of choice. A pyloric length greater than 16 mm and the transverse diameter of the pyloric muscle greater than 4 mm is diagnostic. Findings seen in ultrasound of CHPS are:

  • Antral nipple sign - It is produced by the double-layered pyloric mucosa protruding into the gastric antrum.
  • Cervix sign - It refers to the uterine cervix-like appearance produced due to the hypertrophic pyloric mucosa.

The child should be rehydrated and the metabolic abnormality has to be corrected preoperatively. The Ramstedt pyloromyotomy is the standard surgical procedure for its treatment.

Related Pearl: Radiological findings in various GI disorders

Duodenal atresia: Double bubble sign

 

Jejunal and ileal atresia: Multiple air-fluid levels (plain erect X-ray abdomen) presenting as triple bubble sign. 

 

Congenital hypertrophic pyloric stenosis: Single enlarged gastric gas bubble - single bubble sign

 

Sigmoid volvulus: Coffee bean sign 

 

Achalasia cardia: Bird-beak sign

 

Small bowel obstruction: The obstructed bowel loops are central in location and show valvulae conniventes (mucosal folds that cross the entire diameter of the bowel) characteristic of jejunal involvement.

Large bowel obstruction: The presence of haustrations is a feature of large bowel obstruction. Haustral folds are irregular and do not cross the entire diameter of the bowel. These are absent in the caecum. 

 

Caecal volvulus: Presence of caecal dilatation, single air-fluid level extending into the left upper quadrant, and absence of gas in the distal colon. The colonic haustrations are well maintained.

 

Midgut volvulus: Corkscrew appearance showing the duodenum and jejunum spiraling around the mesenteric vessels in upper GI contrast studies.

 

Necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC): Abdominal X-ray findings include pneumatosis intestinalis (air in the bowel wall).

Cystic fibrosis (CF): Abdominal x-ray with contrast enema reveals a microcolon with several meconium plugs.

questions.text: A child was brought to the clinic for evaluation of recurrent urinary tract infections. An intravenous urogram was obtained, as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario and the intravenous urogram showing the drooping lily sign suggest the presence of a duplicated collecting system.

In a duplicated collecting system often, the ureter that supplies the upper half of the kidney becomes obstructed. Suppose the upper pole collecting system of the kidney is completely obstructed. In that case, only the normally draining lower pole collecting system is visualized on the intravenous urogram and looks like a drooping lily.

The duplicated collecting system is a common congenital anomaly of the urinary tract. It occurs due to the division of the ureter as it ascends upwards from the bladder to the renal parenchyma during the embryological period of life. Thus, the person might have two collecting systems for one kidney.

The Weigert-Meyer law describes the relationship of the upper and lower renal moieties in duplicated collecting systems to their drainage inferiorly: When there are abnormalities associated with duplicating collecting systems,

  • The upper pole moiety drains inferomedially and is most commonly associated with obstruction
  • The lower pole moiety drains superolaterally and is most commonly associated with vesicoureteral reflux.

The illustration given below shows the Weigert-Meyer law.

The lower pole ureter is normally inserted into the bladder. However, the upper pole ureter might have an ectopic insertion in the bladder, urethra, or, vagina. 

Ureteropelvic junction obstruction in a patient with duplicated collecting system can be managed with laparoscopic procedures such as pyeloplasty.

Other options:

Option B: Ureterocele is caused due to the dilatation of the ureter as it passes through the bladder wall. It is visualized as a cobra head deformity on a pyelogram.

The image given below shows the cobra head sign.

Option C: Autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease is best visualized on ultrasounds and CT scans where the cyst is usually hypodense in contrast to the renal parenchyma. It may appear hyperdense if there is a hemorrhage present.

The image given below shows CT findings seen in childhood polycystic kidney disease.

Option D: Horseshoe kidney is a common congenital anomaly in which there is a fusion of the inferior poles of both kidneys. It is common in patients with Turner's syndrome.

The image shown below shows CT findings seen in the horseshoe kidney.

Related Pearl: IVU signs and associated conditions

Medullary sponge kidney 

  • Bouquet of flowers/ paintbrush appearance
  • It refers to the cystic dilatation of the distal collecting tubules

Duplex kidney

  • Drooping lily sign
  • It refers to the inferolateral displacement of the lower pole due to an obstructed upper pole in a duplicated collecting system

Horseshoe kidney

  • Handshake sign - due to the position of the lower poles closer to the spine, and the lower calyces closer to each other
  • Flower vase sign - due to medially rotated calyces

Retroperitoneal fibrosis

  • Maiden waist deformity 
  • It refers to the medially drawn ureters caused by fibrosis at the lumbosacral junction

Retrocaval ureter 

  • Fish hook / Reverse J deformity 
  • Right ureter hooks behind the IVC as it passes posterior to it

Ureterocele

  • Cobra/ Adder head appearance
  • It refers to the dilation of the distal ureter

Transitional cell carcinoma of the ureter

  • Goblet sign
  • It is due to the focal dilation of the ureter by an intraluminal mass

questions.text: A 13-year old boy presents to you with limitation of abduction and internal rotation of the left hip. The X-ray appearance of his left hip joint is shown in the below image. What is the diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
Trethowan's sign is seen in the x-ray and the diagnosis is slipped capital femoral epiphysis (SCFE).

The Klein line is a line along the superior aspect of the femoral neck which normally intersects the epiphysis.

In SCFE, Klein's line does not intersect the epiphysis and passes superior to it. This is known as Trethowan's sign.

Slipped femoral capital epiphysis:

SCFE occurs during the period of rapid growth with the average age of presentation around 12 years.

Risk factors: Obesity, hypothyroidism, growth hormone excess, and chronic renal failure are all-important associations of SCFE.

Clinical features:

  • Patients with SCFE typically present in the rapid growth phase of adolescence with pain in the thigh, groin, or knee.
  • On examination, the affected limb is shortened and externally rotated.
  • There is a limitation in abduction, flexion, and internal rotation on the affected side.
  • Flexion of the hip might lead to obligate external rotation and abduction - positive Drehmann’s sign.
  • Patients may have an antalgic or Trendelenburg gait.

Other radiological findings include:

  • Wide or irregular physis with loss of the anterior head-neck concavity
  • Sharp metaphyseal border of the head
  • Loss of total epiphyseal height
  • Steel sign (Metaphyseal blanch sign) - The posteriorly displaced femoral epiphysis overlaps over the metaphysis causing a crescent-shaped area of increased density on the AP radiograph.
  • Capener’s sign –the metaphysis displaces laterally, worsening the slip and causes a reduction in the double-density crescent created by the overlap of the posterior acetabulum and proximal metaphysis on the AP radiograph.
  • Southwick angle – The angle between the line drawn perpendicular to the physis and a line parallel to the femoral shaft. As slip worsens, the Southwick angle will increase. It is measured on the frog lateral X-ray view.

Other options:

Perthes disease:

It is characterized by idiopathic avascular necrosis of the proximal femoral epiphysis. This condition commonly affects children of 4-8 years of age. The child has pain in the hip while performing passive movements. The radiograph shows features of bone necrosis followed by remodeling.

Developmental Dysplasia of the hip: It is characterized by spontaneous dislocation of the hip joint before, during, or shortly after birth. This condition is more common in females. Children with this condition have a waddling gait and on examination abduction and lateral rotation of the hip is decreased. X-ray shows a broken Shenton's line and the femoral head lies in the upper and outer quadrant formed by the Hilgenreiner’s line and the Perkin’s line.

The image given below shows the vertical Perkin's line and the horizontal Hilgenreiner’s line. Normally the femoral head lies in the inner and lower quadrant formed by these lines. But in DDH the femoral head is in the upper and outer quadrant.

Ankylosing spondylitis: It is a chronic progressive inflammatory condition affecting the sacroiliac joints and the axial skeleton. It is commonly seen in young male adults and they typically present with an insidious onset back pain that improves with exercise. The earliest radiological finding is erosion and fuzziness of the sacroiliac joints and the characteristic late sign is the bamboo-spine appearance.

X-ray showing bamboo-spine appearance-

questions.text: Shown below is the pelvic ultrasound image of a 28-year-old female patient with a positive urine pregnancy test. She gave a history of recent treatment for infertility. Identify the classical radiological finding shown in her right adnexa.
questions.solution:
The image shows the bagel sign seen in tubal ectopic pregnancy.

The bagel sign is also known as the tubal ring sign or the blob sign. It refers to the appearance of a gestational sac in the adnexa with a hyperechoic ring. It is characteristic of tubal ectopic pregnancy. This sign has a positive predictive value of 95% in ectopic pregnancy. 

A normal corpus luteum can also mimic this sign but can be differentiated by a bimanual pelvic examination.

A ring of fire appearance is seen on the colour doppler in ectopic pregnancy on the periphery of the adnexal mass.  It is shown in the image below:

Other options:

Option A, Lambda sign: It is also known as the twin-peak sign and is seen in dichorionic pregnancy. The below image shows a schematic diagram of the twin-peak sign. A triangular portion of the placenta is seen insinuating between the amniochorion layers.

Option C: Double decidual sac sign on ultrasound is seen in early intrauterine pregnancy, as two concentric echogenic rings surrounding the gestational sac. It is shown in the image below.

 Option D: T sign is a USG finding in monochorionic gestation. It is thin and is T-shaped because there is no extension of placental tissue or chorion in between the intertwin membrane. It is as shown below.

Normal USG appearance of an intrauterine gestational sac.

The chorionic tissue in between the two layers of the membrane between the twins.

USG sign seen in monochorionic twins. As the intertwin membrane does not have any chorionic tissue it gives rise to ‘T’ sign in ultrasound.

USG appearance of multiple cystic spaces or lesions in a complete mole.

Normal appearance of the choroid plexuses on axial imaging of the fetal brain. An absence of this sign suggests holoprosencephaly.

Seen in craniosynostosis
Empty amnion sign
Visualization of an amniotic sac without concomitant visualization of an embryo. It is an indicator of pregnancy failure.

questions.text: Identify the mode in USG.
questions.solution:
The USG image represents the M-mode used for echocardiography. Echo intensity is represented as brightness and a trace is swept across the screen so that the x-axis represents time.

Ultrasonography is a versatile imaging modality known for its portability and safety, particularly as it does not involve radiation exposure. As the safest radiological investigation for pregnancy, it provides crucial information without posing any risks to the mother or fetus, making it indispensable in obstetric care. 

Different modes in USG and its uses are as follows:

  1. A (amplitude) mode: Used in ophthalmology and orbital biometry (option A).
  2. B (brightness) mode: Used for all routine applications, with brightness encoded as grayscale value (option B).
  3. M (motion) mode: In echocardiography. 

HIFU (high-intensity focussed USG) is a therapeutic application of USG. It is useful for the treatment of fibroids. HIFU exploits the thermal effects of high-powered, tightly focused ultrasound beams so that very small target tissues can be heated and coagulated.

The image below depicts a duplex scan, which is a combination of B-mode imaging and pulsed Doppler data acquisition.

Doppler ultrasound (option D) is used in diagnosing peripheral arterial disease. It uses a handheld Doppler ultrasound probe placed at an arterial site. A normal arterial wave has a triphasic signal. A triphasic wave has three waveforms consisting of a sharp systolic wave with a forward uprise and fall, a second wave with reverse flow occurring in diastole, and the last wave with a forward flow taking place during diastole. 

Doppler ultrasound can detect moving blood. However, it does not provide information on whether the blood flow is sufficient for the maintenance of limb viability.

questions.text: A patient is undergoing Doppler ultrasonographic assessment for varicose veins. When the probe was placed inferior to the inguinal crease, the sign shown in the below image was seen on the transverse view in the B-mode. What does it indicate?
questions.solution:
The sign in the image given above is the Mickey mouse sign, which represents the normal anatomy of the femoral vessels.

The Mickey mouse sign is seen on the transverse B-mode of USG.

It includes 

  • Great saphenous vein (GSV),
  • Common femoral vein (CFV), and
  • Common femoral artery (CFA)

Normally, the GSV and CFV lie medial to the common femoral artery, which gives rise to the sign.

Mickey mouse in medicine:

  • Mickey mouse appearance - seen on antenatal ultrasound, due to absent cranial bone/brain and bulging orbits in anencephaly
  • Mickey mouse appearance - seen on MRI in progressive supranuclear palsy
  • The Mickey Mouse sign also represents the configuration of the portal triad - the portal vein, common bile duct, and the hepatic artery on biliary ultrasound.

questions.text:
A 58-year-old male patient presented to the outpatient department with complaints of heaviness of head, swelling on the forehead, and dull headache throughout the day. The image shows a CT scan of the skull. Biochemical tests show raised alkaline phosphatase and normal serum calcium. The most likely diagnosis is?

CT - Computed tomography
questions.solution:
The given image shows Tam o'Shanter sign and clinical findings suggest Paget's disease of bone or osteitis deformans.

Paget's disease is characterized by increased osteoclastic activity leading to increased bone turnover. This causes localized sites of lysis and excavations in bone. This is followed by enlargement and thickening of the bone because of increased osteoblastic activity. The internal architecture is abnormal and the bone is unusually brittle. Raised levels of plasma alkaline phosphatase is seen. Serum calcium and phosphate levels are usually normal

The radiological signs seen are:

  • Osteoporosis circumscripta: large, well-defined lytic lesion of the involved bone.
  • Cotton wool appearance: mixed lytic and sclerotic lesions of the skull
  • Diploic widening: both inner and outer calvarial tables are involved, with the former usually more extensively affected.
  • Tam o'Shanter sign: frontal bone enlargement, with the appearance of the skull falling over the facial bones, like a Tam o' Shanter hat.

Image shows cotton wool appearance of skull seen in Paget's disease.

Tam o'Shanter hat sign in skull radiograph resembling the Scottish Tam o'Shanter hat.

Other options:

Option B: Hyperparathyroidism is caused due to increased parathyroid hormone. It causes osteoclastic resorption of bone leading to raised calcium levels and complications of hypercalcemia like renal stones, abdominal pain, depression. Sub-periosteal resorption of the phalanges is a diagnostic feature of hyperparathyroidism. The x-ray skull shows a salt pepper appearance showing a well-marked stippling, but the opaque areas are small pinhead size.

Image shows salt and pepper appearance seen in hyperparathyroidism.

Option C: Osteopetrosis occurs due to a defect in the genes that control the osteoclastic activity and hence usually presents much earlier in life. Plain radiographs are usually diagnostic. The bones appear sclerotic and the skull base is uniformly radiodense. Radiolucent bands through sclerotic vertebrae are often seen and referred to as the ‘rugger-jersey’ sign. The skull base shows uniform radiodensity
 

An X-ray image showing dense bones seen in osteopetrosis is shown below.

Option D: Osteomyelitis can occur in the frontal bone is associated with forehead swelling and redness. It usually results from acute frontal sinusitis but can also occur as sequelae of trauma or surgery. Pus can be formed under the periosteum as soft boggy swelling called pott's puffy tumor. ESR and CRP are elevated with leukocytosis, serum calcium and ALP are usually unchanged. X-ray is done initially but a CT scan clinches the diagnosis. Radionuclide scanning, MRI are other radiological investigations that are used.

Image shows MRI, T1, sagittal, gadolinium contrast showing pott's puffy tumor, spreading towards patients' brain.

Related Pearl: Pathological fracture

Pathological fractures occur with normal stresses in the bones that have been weakened by a change in its structure or through a lytic lesion.

Factors suggestive of a pathologic fracture:

  • Fracture after minor trauma
  • Pain at the site before the fracture
  • Multiple recent fractures
  • History of primary malignancy

Causes:

1. Generalized bone disease: 

  • Osteoporosis
  • Metabolic bone diseases
  • Osteogenesis imperfecta
  • Paget's disease
  • Polyostotic fibrous dysplasia
  • Myelomatosis

2. Local benign conditions:

  • Chronic infection
  • Solitary bone cyst
  • Aneurysmal bone cyst
  • Chondroma

3. Primary malignant tumors:

  • Chondrosarcoma
  • Osteosarcoma
  • Ewing's tumor

4. Metastatic tumors

  • Mets from breast, lung, kidney, thyroid, colon and prostate

questions.text: Hysterosalpingography was done in a patient to evaluate the patency of fallopian tubes, and the following finding is seen. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given hysterosalpingography image shows the typical "tobacco pouch" appearance of the fallopian tube, which is highly suggestive of tuberculous salpingitis caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis.

Genital tuberculosis: The leading presenting complaints include infertility, menstrual irregularities, abdominal pain, vaginal discharge, and suspicion of neoplasm. 10-15% of women are found to be asymptomatic as well.

Investigation:

1. Complete blood count, erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR), enzyme-linked immunoabsorbent assay (ELISA) tests - lgG and IgM, and Mantoux tests are done to evaluate the case of genital tuberculosis. The nucleic acid amplification technique (NAAT) can detect tuberculosis within a few hours compared to culture.

2. Hysterosalpingography- If genital tuberculosis is suspected, it should not be performed because of the risk of spread of infection.

If performed in an asymptomatic woman, the following patterns may be seen:

  • Rigid non-peristaltic pipe-like tube (lead-pipe appearance)
  • Beading and variation in filling defect
  • Calcification of the tube
  • Cornual block
  • Jagged fluffiness of the tubal outline
  • Tobacco-pouch appearance of hydrosalpinx and pyosalpinx with blocked fimbrial end
  • Golf club appearance with slight or moderate dilatation of the ampullary portion of the fallopian tube.
  • Rosette-type of appearance secondary to multiple small diverticular-like outpouchings surrounding the ampulla produced by caseous ulceration.

3. Endometrial histology and PCR testing: Endometrium tissue is obtained by D&C/hystroscopy-directed biopsy. The late premenstrual phase is the ideal time to schedule this procedure. The endometrial scrapings are used for histopathology, PCR testing, and AFB smear and culture. PCR is a rapid, sensitive, and specific method of detecting mycobacterial DNA.

4. Laparoscopy: Diagnostic laparoscopy is widely used to establish the diagnosis of genital tuberculosis/ abdominal pelvic tuberculosis. Tuberculous lesions can be seen on the parietal peritoneum, intestinal serosa, omentum, surface of the uterus, and fallopian tubes.

The image below shows the "pipe stem" or "lead pipe" appearance. There is an absence of normal tortuosity and a curved or straight pipe-like appearance shows the fibrotic stage of tuberculous salpingitis. 

The image below shows multiple constrictions along the fallopian tube giving rise to a "beaded" appearance.

Image below shows sacculation of both tubes in distal portion with an associated hydrosalpinx giving a Golf club-like appearance.

Image below shows " Tobacco pouch" appearance of the fallopian tube.

All the other options - N. gonorrhea, C. trachomatis, and Mycoplasma hominis are causative agents for pelvic inflammatory disease (PID). Acute PID presents with abdominal pain and tenderness where sonography is a primary imaging tool. Normal fallopian tubes are rarely imaged. Characteristic acute findings include: a distended, ovoid-shaped tube filled with anechoic or echogenic fluid, fallopian tube wall thickening, incomplete internal septa, and a "cogwheel" appearance when inflamed tubes are imaged in cross-section.
